title: How to Prepare Greek Yogurt

steps.headline: Warm the milk to 200 °F (93 °C).
steps.description: Transfer the milk to a large Dutch oven that can hold at least 3 quarts (2.8 L). Heat the milk over medium-high heat, stirring regularly to prevent the bottom from burning. Insert a candy thermometer into the milk and bring the milk to a full simmer, which is around 200 °F (93 °C). Heating the milk to an almost boil will help the yogurt set, rather than form separated curds and whey. You can use any milk you like for this recipe, including non-dairy milks such as soy or coconut. You can also use dairy milk. Whole milk or 2 percent will produce a creamier yogurt, but you can use skim or 1 percent as well.

steps.headline: Cool the milk to 115 °F (46 °C).
steps.description: Once the milk reaches 200 °F (93 °C), remove it from the heat and set it aside to cool to between 112 and 115 °F (44 and 46 °C). This is the ideal temperature for adding and growing the bacterial cultures that will convert the milk into yogurt. Stir regularly as the milk cools to help it cool faster and prevent a skin from forming. Cooling the milk to this temperature may take up to an hour.

steps.headline: Turn on the light in your oven.
steps.description: To make yogurt, you have to keep the milk and bacterial cultures that you’ll add later at around 110 °F (43 °C) for several hours. This is around the temperature your oven gets when you turn the light on but leave the heat off, so you can incubate the yogurt in the oven. Remove the middle rack to make room for the Dutch oven. Instead of incubating the yogurt in the oven, you can also use a yogurt maker or dehydrator to incubate the yogurt. If you don’t have either of these appliances, you can transfer the yogurt to a thermos to keep it warm.

steps.headline: Dissolve the commercial yogurt in 1 cup (235 ml) of the warm milk.
steps.description: When the milk reaches the right temperature, remove a cup (235 ml) from the Dutch oven and transfer it to a small bowl. Add the commercial yogurt and whisk the mixture to fully incorporate the milk and yogurt. Use a commercial yogurt that contains active cultures, because the cultures in the yogurt will start your new batch. The yogurt container label will specify if it contains active cultures. Instead of commercial yogurt, you can also use freeze-dried yogurt starter. Read the instructions on the package for the exact measurements and directions. Typically, you'll stir ⅛ teaspoon of yogurt starter powder it into the warm milk. Reseal the yogurt starter and return it to the freezer.

steps.headline: Combine the yogurt and the rest of the warm milk.
steps.description: Pour the yogurt mixture into the Dutch oven with the rest of the milk. Whisk the mixture slowly and gently to combine everything and help distribute the bacterial culture throughout the milk.

steps.headline: Wrap the Dutch oven in a towel.
steps.description: Put the lid on the Dutch oven and wrap the entire thing in a large tea towel or small beach towel. The bacteria need to remain between 110 and 115 °F (43 and 46 °C) in order to turn the milk into yogurt, and wrapping the Dutch oven with a towel will help keep them warm and at a constant temperature. If you're using a yogurt maker or dehydrator instead, transfer the milk to individual yogurt or mason jars.

steps.headline: Transfer the milk to the oven for 4 to 8 hours.
steps.description: Open the oven door and carefully move the Dutch oven into the oven that’s been prewarmed to about 110 °F (43 °C) with the light. After 4 hours, carefully remove the Dutch oven and check the yogurt to see if it has set. If the yogurt hasn’t thickened to your liking, place it back in the oven for another 1 to 4 hours, until it reaches your desired consistency. Typically, the yogurt should have the consistency of custard. As the yogurt incubates, it will continue to become thicker and tarter.

steps.headline: Remove the yogurt from the oven and spoon off the liquid.
steps.description: When the yogurt has reached your desired thickness, remove the Dutch oven and turn off the oven light. Take off the lid and use a spoon to collect and remove any liquid that has settled on top of the yogurt.

steps.headline: Line a fine-mesh strainer with cheesecloth.
steps.description: Fold the cheesecloth 3 or 4 times and place it inside the strainer. Set the strainer on top of a bowl to catch the whey that drips out. The main difference between regular yogurt and Greek yogurt is the amount of whey, so you can turn regular yogurt into Greek-style by straining out the excess whey to make a thicker yogurt. You can also use a flour sack towel or tea towel if you don’t have cheesecloth.

steps.headline: Pour the yogurt into the strainer.
steps.description: Use a large spoon to transfer the yogurt from the Dutch oven to the cheesecloth-lined strainer. Scrape out as much yogurt as you can from the Dutch oven. Transfer the strainer and bowl setup to the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Leave the yogurt to drain in the refrigerator for up to 6 hours.
steps.description: As the yogurt sits in the strainer, the excess whey will drip down into the bowl below. You can start checking the consistency of the yogurt after 2 hours, but it may need up to 6 to achieve the thickness you want.

steps.headline: Transfer the yogurt to an airtight container.
steps.description: When the yogurt has been strained, use a spoon to transfer it from the cheesecloth to an airtight container, such as a mason jar or food storage container. Scrape the cheesecloth to remove as much Greek yogurt as possible. Stir the yogurt with a spoon or small whisk to make it smooth.

steps.headline: Reserve the whey for baking and other uses.
steps.description:
The whey that collects in the bowl below the strainer is full of protein, vitamins, and other nutrients. Transfer the whey to an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator for up to 6 months. To use the whey, you can:
Blend it into smoothies. Use it to make the brine for pickles. Add it to baked goods in place of water. Add it to soups.

steps.headline: Enjoy it plain or with fruit.
steps.description:
Greek yogurt is a delicious snack or meal all on its own. You can eat it in the morning, at lunch, or as a snack at any time of day. You can also stir in bite-sized pieces of your favorite fruit, or spice up the yogurt by adding:
Honey, maple syrup, or other sweeteners
Cinnamon
Fresh or ground ginger
Cocoa powder
Granola
Oats
Puffed rice

steps.headline: Blend it up in a smoothie.
steps.description: A fruit and yogurt smoothie is a great way to start the day or replenish your body after exercise. You can even customize the smoothie by adding your favorite fruits, spices, and juices.

steps.headline: Whip up a batch of tzatziki.
steps.description: Dice half a cucumber and transfer the pieces to a bowl. Sprinkle the cucumber with salt and leave it for about 10 minutes. Gently squeeze the cucumbers with your hands, and transfer them to a strainer. In a large bowl, combine the cucumber, 1 cup (245 g) of yogurt, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of olive oil, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice, 1 minced clove of garlic, and ¼ cup (6 g) of chopped mint. Stir to combine all the ingredients. Tzatziki can be used as a sauce on wraps, meats, and vegetables, or as a dip for breads and other food as well.

steps.headline: Store leftover yogurt in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.
steps.description: As long as you store your homemade Greek yogurt in an airtight container, it will last in the refrigerator for up to 14 days, which is about the same as store-bought. You can also reserve ½ cup (123 g) of the yogurt to make a new batch from scratch.

text:
Making the Yogurt Warm the milk to 200 °F (93 °C). Transfer the milk to a large Dutch oven that can hold at least 3 quarts (2.8 L). Heat the milk over medium-high heat, stirring regularly to prevent the bottom from burning. Insert a candy thermometer into the milk and bring the milk to a full simmer, which is around 200 °F (93 °C). Heating the milk to an almost boil will help the yogurt set, rather than form separated curds and whey. You can use any milk you like for this recipe, including non-dairy milks such as soy or coconut. You can also use dairy milk. Whole milk or 2 percent will produce a creamier yogurt, but you can use skim or 1 percent as well. Cool the milk to 115 °F (46 °C). Once the milk reaches 200 °F (93 °C), remove it from the heat and set it aside to cool to between 112 and 115 °F (44 and 46 °C). This is the ideal temperature for adding and growing the bacterial cultures that will convert the milk into yogurt. Stir regularly as the milk cools to help it cool faster and prevent a skin from forming. Cooling the milk to this temperature may take up to an hour. Turn on the light in your oven. To make yogurt, you have to keep the milk and bacterial cultures that you’ll add later at around 110 °F (43 °C) for several hours. This is around the temperature your oven gets when you turn the light on but leave the heat off, so you can incubate the yogurt in the oven. Remove the middle rack to make room for the Dutch oven. Instead of incubating the yogurt in the oven, you can also use a yogurt maker or dehydrator to incubate the yogurt. If you don’t have either of these appliances, you can transfer the yogurt to a thermos to keep it warm. Dissolve the commercial yogurt in 1 cup (235 ml) of the warm milk. When the milk reaches the right temperature, remove a cup (235 ml) from the Dutch oven and transfer it to a small bowl. Add the commercial yogurt and whisk the mixture to fully incorporate the milk and yogurt. Use a commercial yogurt that contains active cultures, because the cultures in the yogurt will start your new batch. The yogurt container label will specify if it contains active cultures. Instead of commercial yogurt, you can also use freeze-dried yogurt starter. Read the instructions on the package for the exact measurements and directions. Typically, you'll stir ⅛ teaspoon of yogurt starter powder it into the warm milk. Reseal the yogurt starter and return it to the freezer. Combine the yogurt and the rest of the warm milk. Pour the yogurt mixture into the Dutch oven with the rest of the milk. Whisk the mixture slowly and gently to combine everything and help distribute the bacterial culture throughout the milk. Wrap the Dutch oven in a towel. Put the lid on the Dutch oven and wrap the entire thing in a large tea towel or small beach towel. The bacteria need to remain between 110 and 115 °F (43 and 46 °C) in order to turn the milk into yogurt, and wrapping the Dutch oven with a towel will help keep them warm and at a constant temperature. If you're using a yogurt maker or dehydrator instead, transfer the milk to individual yogurt or mason jars. Transfer the milk to the oven for 4 to 8 hours. Open the oven door and carefully move the Dutch oven into the oven that’s been prewarmed to about 110 °F (43 °C) with the light. After 4 hours, carefully remove the Dutch oven and check the yogurt to see if it has set. If the yogurt hasn’t thickened to your liking, place it back in the oven for another 1 to 4 hours, until it reaches your desired consistency. Typically, the yogurt should have the consistency of custard. As the yogurt incubates, it will continue to become thicker and tarter. Remove the yogurt from the oven and spoon off the liquid. When the yogurt has reached your desired thickness, remove the Dutch oven and turn off the oven light. Take off the lid and use a spoon to collect and remove any liquid that has settled on top of the yogurt. Straining the Yogurt Line a fine-mesh strainer with cheesecloth. Fold the cheesecloth 3 or 4 times and place it inside the strainer. Set the strainer on top of a bowl to catch the whey that drips out. The main difference between regular yogurt and Greek yogurt is the amount of whey, so you can turn regular yogurt into Greek-style by straining out the excess whey to make a thicker yogurt. You can also use a flour sack towel or tea towel if you don’t have cheesecloth. Pour the yogurt into the strainer. Use a large spoon to transfer the yogurt from the Dutch oven to the cheesecloth-lined strainer. Scrape out as much yogurt as you can from the Dutch oven. Transfer the strainer and bowl setup to the refrigerator. Leave the yogurt to drain in the refrigerator for up to 6 hours. As the yogurt sits in the strainer, the excess whey will drip down into the bowl below. You can start checking the consistency of the yogurt after 2 hours, but it may need up to 6 to achieve the thickness you want. Transfer the yogurt to an airtight container. When the yogurt has been strained, use a spoon to transfer it from the cheesecloth to an airtight container, such as a mason jar or food storage container. Scrape the cheesecloth to remove as much Greek yogurt as possible. Stir the yogurt with a spoon or small whisk to make it smooth. Reserve the whey for baking and other uses. The whey that collects in the bowl below the strainer is full of protein, vitamins, and other nutrients. Transfer the whey to an airtight container and store it in the refrigerator for up to 6 months. To use the whey, you can:
Blend it into smoothies. Use it to make the brine for pickles. Add it to baked goods in place of water. Add it to soups. Storing and Serving the Yogurt Enjoy it plain or with fruit. Greek yogurt is a delicious snack or meal all on its own. You can eat it in the morning, at lunch, or as a snack at any time of day. You can also stir in bite-sized pieces of your favorite fruit, or spice up the yogurt by adding:
Honey, maple syrup, or other sweeteners
Cinnamon
Fresh or ground ginger
Cocoa powder
Granola
Oats
Puffed rice Blend it up in a smoothie. A fruit and yogurt smoothie is a great way to start the day or replenish your body after exercise. You can even customize the smoothie by adding your favorite fruits, spices, and juices. Whip up a batch of tzatziki. Dice half a cucumber and transfer the pieces to a bowl. Sprinkle the cucumber with salt and leave it for about 10 minutes. Gently squeeze the cucumbers with your hands, and transfer them to a strainer. In a large bowl, combine the cucumber, 1 cup (245 g) of yogurt, 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of olive oil, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of lemon juice, 1 minced clove of garlic, and ¼ cup (6 g) of chopped mint. Stir to combine all the ingredients. Tzatziki can be used as a sauce on wraps, meats, and vegetables, or as a dip for breads and other food as well. Store leftover yogurt in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. As long as you store your homemade Greek yogurt in an airtight container, it will last in the refrigerator for up to 14 days, which is about the same as store-bought. You can also reserve ½ cup (123 g) of the yogurt to make a new batch from scratch.
